title: Introspection query leaks sensitive graphql system information.

profile.name: HackerOne
profile.about: Vulnerability disclosure should be safe, transparent, and rewarding.

vulnerability_information:
**Summary:**
Interospection query leaks sensitive data.

**Introduction**
As we know graphql was initially developed and used by facebook as an **internal query language** and so the features of graphql mostly revolve around internal and development areas.
Graphql executes queries using a type system with the data defined. An important but often ignored feature of graphql is the ability to ask graphql schema about the supported queries with the help of **Interospection Sytem**

**Description (includes Impact and Steps to Reproduce)**
An interospection system can completely reveal the backend system defined by developers inluding arguments,fields,types,descriptions,deprecated status of types and so on. 
This could easily give out the complete map of backend system along with the schema and directives. 

In our case graphql is implemented as an [endpoint] (https://hackerone.com/graphql) to retrieve sensitive data like user information, payout preferences, program policies, team settings etc.
Revealing the schema of the entire backend will serve as an attack ground for attackers in order to craft graphql queries that can retrieve fields that are normally not meant to be accessed by users.
Moreover any changes made or to be brought about can be easily revealed through **description** fields of types.

The following graphql query is an **interospection query** that completely reveals the defined system with all required details ([Reference] (https://gist.github.com/craigbeck/b90915d49fda19d5b2b17ead14dcd6da)). 

`{"query": "query IntrospectionQuery {__schema {queryType { name },mutationType { name },subscriptionType { name },types {...FullType},directives {name,description,args {...InputValue},onOperation,onFragment,onField}}}\nfragment FullType on __Type {kind,name,description,fields(includeDeprecated: true) {name,description,args {...InputValue},type {...TypeRef},isDeprecated,deprecationReason},inputFields {...InputValue},interfaces {...TypeRef},enumValues(includeDeprecated: true) {name,description,isDeprecated,deprecationReason},possibleTypes {...TypeRef}}\nfragment InputValue on __InputValue {name,description,type { ...TypeRef },defaultValue}\nfragment TypeRef on __Type {kind,name,ofType {kind,name,ofType {kind,name,ofType {kind,name}}}}"}`

Upon looking into the response (ie the graphql system map returned), following things were observed:

+ **Deprecated Nodes could still be queried at root level**

The interospection query response returned deprecated status of nodes like "Report","Team" as "true":

eg.
> "isDeprecated": true,
  "deprecationReason": "Query for a <Node Name> node at the root level is not recommended. Ref T12456" 

But it was seen that a graphql query could still be created with above nodes as root. 

eg. Query with Node **Team** at root level:

**Steps to Reproduce**

`{"query": "query {team(handle:\"security\"){id,_id,about,base_bounty,bug_count}}"}`

This returned valid data even if it was supposed to be deprecated:

> {
	"data": {
		"team": {
			"id": "Z2lkOi8vaGFja2Vyb25lL1RlYW0vMTM=",
			"_id": "13",
			"about": "Vulnerability disclosure should be safe, transparent, and rewarding.",
			"base_bounty": 500,
			"bug_count": 236
		}
	}
}

This holds true for all nodes that shouldnt be allowed to query directly at root level: Report, Team, User.

**Impact**
Node queries not meant to be allowed at root level could still be executed and could potentially leak data not to be retrieved otherwise. 


+ **Additional Fields of Nodes can be disclosed**

The fields that are not retrieved normally could be retrieved due to knowledge of all fields on a type (or OBJECT). 

eg. the fields sla_missed_count sla_failed-count for a team:

**Steps to Reproduce** 
`{"query": "query {team(handle:\"security\"){sla_failed_count,sla_missed_count}}"}`

> {
	"data": {
		"team": {
			"sla_failed_count": 0,
			"sla_missed_count": 0
		}
	}
}

This was also possible due to "team" being allowed at root level.

**Impact**
Disclosure of additional fields on Nodes


+ **Description field leaks future implementations**

> "deprecationReason": "This is about to be replaced by .genius_execution" 
> "deprecationReason": "Deprecated in favor of .original_report" 

These were returned as deprecationReason fields for genius_execution_id and original_report_id respectively. 

**Impact**
May leak future implementations


**Possible fix**
As mentioned before, graphql was originally used as internal query language and so features like "Interospection System" was useful for development.
But When it is used as a method to query sensitive data, it becomes a threat. Interospection queries should be disabled.


Regards,
Zuriel
vulnerability_information_html:
Summary:
Interospection query leaks sensitive data.

Introduction
As we know graphql was initially developed and used by facebook as an internal query language and so the features of graphql mostly revolve around internal and development areas.
Graphql executes queries using a type system with the data defined. An important but often ignored feature of graphql is the ability to ask graphql schema about the supported queries with the help of Interospection Sytem

Description (includes Impact and Steps to Reproduce)
An interospection system can completely reveal the backend system defined by developers inluding arguments,fields,types,descriptions,deprecated status of types and so on.
This could easily give out the complete map of backend system along with the schema and directives.

In our case graphql is implemented as an endpoint to retrieve sensitive data like user information, payout preferences, program policies, team settings etc.
Revealing the schema of the entire backend will serve as an attack ground for attackers in order to craft graphql queries that can retrieve fields that are normally not meant to be accessed by users.
Moreover any changes made or to be brought about can be easily revealed through description fields of types.

The following graphql query is an interospection query that completely reveals the defined system with all required details (Reference).

{"query": "query IntrospectionQuery {__schema {queryType { name },mutationType { name },subscriptionType { name },types {...FullType},directives {name,description,args {...InputValue},onOperation,onFragment,onField}}}\nfragment FullType on __Type {kind,name,description,fields(includeDeprecated: true) {name,description,args {...InputValue},type {...TypeRef},isDeprecated,deprecationReason},inputFields {...InputValue},interfaces {...TypeRef},enumValues(includeDeprecated: true) {name,description,isDeprecated,deprecationReason},possibleTypes {...TypeRef}}\nfragment InputValue on __InputValue {name,description,type { ...TypeRef },defaultValue}\nfragment TypeRef on __Type {kind,name,ofType {kind,name,ofType {kind,name,ofType {kind,name}}}}"}

Upon looking into the response (ie the graphql system map returned), following things were observed:

  • Deprecated Nodes could still be queried at root level

The interospection query response returned deprecated status of nodes like "Report","Team" as "true":

eg.

"isDeprecated": true,
"deprecationReason": "Query for a <Node Name> node at the root level is not recommended. Ref T12456"

But it was seen that a graphql query could still be created with above nodes as root.

eg. Query with Node Team at root level:

Steps to Reproduce

{"query": "query {team(handle:\"security\"){id,_id,about,base_bounty,bug_count}}"}

This returned valid data even if it was supposed to be deprecated:

{
"data": {
"team": {
"id": "Z2lkOi8vaGFja2Vyb25lL1RlYW0vMTM=",
"_id": "13",
"about": "Vulnerability disclosure should be safe, transparent, and rewarding.",
"base_bounty": 500,
"bug_count": 236
}
}
}

This holds true for all nodes that shouldnt be allowed to query directly at root level: Report, Team, User.

Impact
Node queries not meant to be allowed at root level could still be executed and could potentially leak data not to be retrieved otherwise.

  • Additional Fields of Nodes can be disclosed

The fields that are not retrieved normally could be retrieved due to knowledge of all fields on a type (or OBJECT).

eg. the fields sla_missed_count sla_failed-count for a team:

Steps to Reproduce
{"query": "query {team(handle:\"security\"){sla_failed_count,sla_missed_count}}"}

{
"data": {
"team": {
"sla_failed_count": 0,
"sla_missed_count": 0
}
}
}

This was also possible due to "team" being allowed at root level.

Impact
Disclosure of additional fields on Nodes

  • Description field leaks future implementations

"deprecationReason": "This is about to be replaced by .genius_execution"
"deprecationReason": "Deprecated in favor of .original_report"

These were returned as deprecationReason fields for genius_execution_id and original_report_id respectively.

Impact
May leak future implementations

Possible fix
As mentioned before, graphql was originally used as internal query language and so features like "Interospection System" was useful for development.
But When it is used as a method to query sensitive data, it becomes a threat. Interospection queries should be disabled.

Regards,
Zuriel

activities.message:
I am also attaching a text file that contains the entire response of the "IntrospectionQuery" that was returned. This could help to have a look at the fields returned, in depth.  It also contains third party links as a part of a description, that would have been for internal reference. 

Thank you
activities.markdown_message:
I am also attaching a text file that contains the entire response of the "IntrospectionQuery" that was returned. This could help to have a look at the fields returned, in depth. It also contains third party links as a part of a description, that would have been for internal reference.

Thank you

activities.message:
Let me also mention this as it is very much relevant to this report.

Two days ago I was supposed to report similar bug where the **first_repsonse_time** field of the "team" Node was being leaked due to the same reason. But I noticed that it was already fixed at the time of drafting report :) So I rather chose not to report it, as a fix was already placed rightly.

The root cause is that the fields that are normally not required could also be revealed through **introspection query**

activities.message:
It will also be fair enough to mention some additional information on the same.

Normally, in order to query information about a team, the **team** node is used, which would require an argument **team_handle**, This will return information on the team given by the argument. But when **teams** node is used it returns a list of 90-100 teams filtered by their _id. The below query was used to obtain this

`{"query": "query {teams{total_count,edges{node{id,_id,about,handle,state}}}}"}` 
Response: {F240914}

This also returned teams that are **disabled** like nearby, uzbey. Which are normally not displayed when `domain:` filter is used in the directory. 

 Similarly with nodes **users** with query: 

`{"query": "query {users{total_count,edges{node{id,_id,name,username,bio}}}}"}`
Response: {F240915}
activities.markdown_message:
It will also be fair enough to mention some additional information on the same.

Normally, in order to query information about a team, the team node is used, which would require an argument team_handle, This will return information on the team given by the argument. But when teams node is used it returns a list of 90-100 teams filtered by their _id. The below query was used to obtain this

{"query": "query {teams{total_count,edges{node{id,_id,about,handle,state}}}}"}
Response: h1_teams.txt (F240914)

This also returned teams that are disabled like nearby, uzbey. Which are normally not displayed when domain: filter is used in the directory.

Similarly with nodes users with query:

{"query": "query {users{total_count,edges{node{id,_id,name,username,bio}}}}"}
Response: h1_users.txt (F240915)

activities.message:
Sorry for not mentioning every observations together. The response returned by the introspection query is vast and going through the response took time and so the delay. 

It was also seen that several fields reveal themselves as the *primary key of the database*,  in the description field:

>  "name": "_id",
					"description": "The primary key from the database"

This was seen for the _id fields of nodes: Team, TeamMember, SlackPipeline, CommonResponse and ExternalProgram

These observations can be found in {F240670}
activities.markdown_message:
Sorry for not mentioning every observations together. The response returned by the introspection query is vast and going through the response took time and so the delay.

It was also seen that several fields reveal themselves as the primary key of the database, in the description field:

"name": "_id",
"description": "The primary key from the database"

This was seen for the _id fields of nodes: Team, TeamMember, SlackPipeline, CommonResponse and ExternalProgram

These observations can be found in h1_introspection_query_response.txt (F240670)

activities.message:
@zuriel 

Thanks for your submission. Unfortunately, this has already been submitted before.

FYI, all information returned by graphSQL is meant to be public and no sensitive information is retrieved.

Best Regards.
activities.markdown_message:
@zuriel

Thanks for your submission. Unfortunately, this has already been submitted before.

Best Regards.

activities.message:
@glassofbeer #230244 is still undisclosed, so I do not know what that report contains. But as I mentioned before, intersection query can serve as an attack ground to create graphql queries to reveal sensitive information, even if it in itself may not be critical.

The observations mentioned above are some of the many discovered. What do u have to say about the description that reveals _id as **the primary key from database**. Isnt that considered as a leak? Why should the *primary key* of a database be disclosed anyway?
activities.markdown_message:
@glassofbeer #230244 is still undisclosed, so I do not know what that report contains. But as I mentioned before, intersection query can serve as an attack ground to create graphql queries to reveal sensitive information, even if it in itself may not be critical.

The observations mentioned above are some of the many discovered. What do u have to say about the description that reveals _id as the primary key from database. Isnt that considered as a leak? Why should the primary key of a database be disclosed anyway?

activities.message:
@glassofbeer Also apart from introspection query, i had also mentioned about graphql queries as a whole like deprecated nodes at root level and also several fields that aren't returned normally. 

I hope you had a look at them. I request you to look into them if not already. Thank you
activities.markdown_message:
@glassofbeer Also apart from introspection query, i had also mentioned about graphql queries as a whole like deprecated nodes at root level and also several fields that aren't returned normally.

I hope you had a look at them. I request you to look into them if not already. Thank you

activities.message:
Hello @zuriel,

Thanks for diving into our GraphQL endpoint. Since you request any query to it, it's pretty important that we have this adequately secured. 

We don't agree with the security impact of your findings. Let me address them one by one/

Introspection is not something limited to internal use, quite the opposite; it's super useful for external implementers to know how your API/domain works. We even encourage you to use it to make recognizance less of a hassle. The idea is that it makes your hacker life easier and therefore our product more secure.

We're okay with exposing disabled users. For example, you still want to see the reporter's details of an old report filed by a user that's now blocked. To support this, we have to allow you to query blocked users.

Next one, database id. We're, again, entirely okay exposing the database id. There's just no security risk when exposing this number.

Thanks,

Willian
activities.markdown_message:
Hello @zuriel,

Thanks for diving into our GraphQL endpoint. Since you request any query to it, it's pretty important that we have this adequately secured.

We don't agree with the security impact of your findings. Let me address them one by one/

Introspection is not something limited to internal use, quite the opposite; it's super useful for external implementers to know how your API/domain works. We even encourage you to use it to make recognizance less of a hassle. The idea is that it makes your hacker life easier and therefore our product more secure.

We're okay with exposing disabled users. For example, you still want to see the reporter's details of an old report filed by a user that's now blocked. To support this, we have to allow you to query blocked users.

Next one, database id. We're, again, entirely okay exposing the database id. There's just no security risk when exposing this number.

Thanks,

Willian

activities.message:
@wvdv I understand that there is no security issue and it was intentional. 

But I would like to make a point here. I discovered that the **first_response_time** field was being leaked some days ago while I was digging graphql. Now the first_response_time of a team is normally not returned during any of the responses querying a team information. I came to know that this field exists and is leaking the values only because of the introspection query.

See @wvdv, I am not trying to prove that the introspection system itself is a bug. But if not taken care there might be situations like above mentioned where accidently one could leak fields that are not meant to be revealed. Fortunately it was fixed at the time of drafting a previous report and now it returns null, and so i chose not to report it. I wouldnt have known about it at all, if i had not queried and known that such a field exists on node team. 

So inshort I am just trying to say that, when things are open to users, there are higher chances of a bug being visible, which otherwise would go un-noticed. The scope for an attack is increased. Hope you get my point.

To end it I would like you to confirm the following things too, just to make sure they are intentional too:
1) Graphql query response returns rank of all users although it is denoted by *-* (hiphen) on the profile.
2) Cluster category information and external program id of teams are also returned. {F241240}
3) Total count of teams, users and reports.

Thank you @wvdv for the information and courtesy. :)
activities.markdown_message:
@wvdv I understand that there is no security issue and it was intentional.

But I would like to make a point here. I discovered that the first_response_time field was being leaked some days ago while I was digging graphql. Now the first_response_time of a team is normally not returned during any of the responses querying a team information. I came to know that this field exists and is leaking the values only because of the introspection query.

See @wvdv, I am not trying to prove that the introspection system itself is a bug. But if not taken care there might be situations like above mentioned where accidently one could leak fields that are not meant to be revealed. Fortunately it was fixed at the time of drafting a previous report and now it returns null, and so i chose not to report it. I wouldnt have known about it at all, if i had not queried and known that such a field exists on node team.

So inshort I am just trying to say that, when things are open to users, there are higher chances of a bug being visible, which otherwise would go un-noticed. The scope for an attack is increased. Hope you get my point.

To end it I would like you to confirm the following things too, just to make sure they are intentional too:
1) Graphql query response returns rank of all users although it is denoted by - (hiphen) on the profile.
2) Cluster category information and external program id of teams are also returned. clusters.txt (F241240)
3) Total count of teams, users and reports.

Thank you @wvdv for the information and courtesy. :)

activities.message:
@wvdv I was just going through your comment and realized that you misunderstood me on the database part.

I mentioned that the **_id** field of the nodes Team, TeamMember, SlackPipeline, CommonResponse and ExternalProgram is marked as the **primary key from database**. Revealing that this is the **primary key** of the database. 

I think you misunderstood it with the *database id*. I wanted to point out that the **description reveals the primary key of the database**. And I am not talking about database id.   

Please verify this, Thank you
activities.markdown_message:
@wvdv I was just going through your comment and realized that you misunderstood me on the database part.

I mentioned that the _id field of the nodes Team, TeamMember, SlackPipeline, CommonResponse and ExternalProgram is marked as the primary key from database. Revealing that this is the primary key of the database.

I think you misunderstood it with the database id. I wanted to point out that the description reveals the primary key of the database. And I am not talking about database id.

Please verify this, Thank you

@wvdv  Sorry for the fragmented updates. Could you also tell me why is the **target_signal** for security (hackerone) `-1`? Others have values `0` or `1`. Does that mean we actually lose a signal if we report to hackerone?

Thanks again :)

additional_data.old_title: Interospection query leaks sensitive graphql system information.
additional_data.new_title: Introspection query leaks sensitive graphql system information.

activities.message:
> So inshort I am just trying to say that, when things are open to users, there are higher chances of a bug being visible, which otherwise would go un-noticed. 

That's a good thing, right? We want to secure the actual data, not our schema. 

> I think you misunderstood it with the database id. I wanted to point out that the description reveals the primary key of the database. And I am not talking about database id.

PK and the database id are the same, exposing them is _not_ an issue.

> Could you also tell me why is the target_signal for security (hackerone) -1? Others have values 0 or 1. Does that mean we actually lose a signal if we report to hackerone?

Since this isn't about this security issue, can you send a email to support@hackerone.com with this question?


Thanks and hack on!

Willian
activities.markdown_message:
So inshort I am just trying to say that, when things are open to users, there are higher chances of a bug being visible, which otherwise would go un-noticed.

That's a good thing, right? We want to secure the actual data, not our schema.

I think you misunderstood it with the database id. I wanted to point out that the description reveals the primary key of the database. And I am not talking about database id.

PK and the database id are the same, exposing them is not an issue.

Could you also tell me why is the target_signal for security (hackerone) -1? Others have values 0 or 1. Does that mean we actually lose a signal if we report to hackerone?

Since this isn't about this security issue, can you send a email to support@hackerone.com with this question?

Thanks and hack on!

Willian

activities.message: @zuriel before I have to review our whole GraphQL schema, what do you think? Would you consider rank as private? Same goes for the other fields. Is it something that we _absolutely_ not want to leak and can you think of a feasible attack scenario that leads to a business loss for HackerOne.
activities.markdown_message: @zuriel before I have to review our whole GraphQL schema, what do you think? Would you consider rank as private? Same goes for the other fields. Is it something that we absolutely not want to leak and can you think of a feasible attack scenario that leads to a business loss for HackerOne.

activities.message:
@wvdv The reason I asked you to confirm this is because although rank is contained in the response, why would you not display it? You chose not to display it for a reason, right? Well if that reason is nothing related to security, why not display the rank? 

Well talking about external program id, externals programs could also be a private program. About total counts, it could reveal statistics of the programs. A considerable reduction in statistics could alarm suspicion about the quality of an organization and could reduce reputation.
activities.markdown_message:
@wvdv The reason I asked you to confirm this is because although rank is contained in the response, why would you not display it? You chose not to display it for a reason, right? Well if that reason is nothing related to security, why not display the rank?

Well talking about external program id, externals programs could also be a private program. About total counts, it could reveal statistics of the programs. A considerable reduction in statistics could alarm suspicion about the quality of an organization and could reduce reputation.

activities.message: @wvdv Can we disclose this if everything is fine?
activities.markdown_message: @wvdv Can we disclose this if everything is fine?

activities.message: @wvdv Could you just clarify why the rank field is replaced by `-`, even when the response contains it? Just for the sake of clarity.
activities.markdown_message: @wvdv Could you just clarify why the rank field is replaced by -, even when the response contains it? Just for the sake of clarity.

activities.message: @zuriel sure! Not everyone is ranked, and if you don't have a ranking we show you a `-`. Take my account for example https://hackerone.com/wvdv.
activities.markdown_message: @zuriel sure! Not everyone is ranked, and if you don't have a ranking we show you a -. Take my account for example https://hackerone.com/wvdv.

activities.message: @zuriel sorry, I misunderstood your question! I'll have to see why we show you the `-` instead of the actual number. My guess it has something to do with ordering of users on leaderboards and use cases like that.
activities.markdown_message: @zuriel sorry, I misunderstood your question! I'll have to see why we show you the - instead of the actual number. My guess it has something to do with ordering of users on leaderboards and use cases like that.

activities.message: @wvdv Excatly! There are users who have ranks including you :) but are not shown. I feel ranks above 100 are not shown and replaced by `-`. I was just wondering why this happens? I hope there is no security reason associated with this!
activities.markdown_message: @wvdv Excatly! There are users who have ranks including you :) but are not shown. I feel ranks above 100 are not shown and replaced by -. I was just wondering why this happens? I hope there is no security reason associated with this!

activities.message: @wvdv could you please confirm it?
activities.markdown_message: @wvdv could you please confirm it?

activities.message: @zuriel I can confirm there is no security reason for us not showing ranks above the top 100. It is a purposeful decision. :-)
activities.markdown_message: @zuriel I can confirm there is no security reason for us not showing ranks above the top 100. It is a purposeful decision. :-)
